entry.title: COVID-19 deaths and cases: how do sources compare?
entry.summary: There are three main data sources on the latest Coronavirus outbreak (COVID-19). How do estimates of confirmed cases and deaths compare?

entry.title: How many tests for COVID-19 are being performed around the world?
entry.summary: Testing is crucial to understand the prevalence of the disease, to provide timely treatment to those infected, to understand how the disease evolves, and to ensure that we take measures to stop the disease from spreading.

entry.title: Food waste is responsible for 6% of global greenhouse gas emissions
entry.summary: Food losses and waste – in supply chains and by consumers – account for around one-quarter of greenhouse gas emissions from food. That’s 6% of total global emissions.

entry.title: The carbon footprint of foods: are differences explained by the impacts of methane?
entry.summary: How we treat the climate impacts of methane has a significant difference on the carbon footprint of foods. But even if we exclude methane, meat and dairy products have the highest footprint.

What are the safest sources of energy?
entry.summary: Based on safety and carbon emissions, fossil fuels are the dirtiest and most dangerous, while nuclear and modern renewable energy sources are vastly safer and cleaner.

entry.title: Redesigning Our World in Data: from posts and articles to posts in articles
Less meat is nearly always better than sustainable meat, to reduce your carbon footprint
entry.summary: Despite large differences in farming practices across the world, plant-based protein sources still have a lower footprint than the lowest-impact meat products.

entry.title: Is the world making progress against cancer?
entry.summary: Adjusted for both population growth and aging, mortality from cancer is falling globally.
